Once in the past, in a village, there was an elder who took the daughter of a neighboring elder and made her his wife.
Not long after, she became pregnant and gave birth to a son.
He then told his wife, saying:ğŸ”½You should take good care of this child.
'Now we have this son who eats our food and can also repay our debts for us.

His wife replied to her husband:

The elder entered the ocean but encountered a storm that sank his ship and all his wealth, with no return.

His wife heard that her husband had died, observed mourning, cultivated blessings, and also hired herself out to work, while her relatives each helped each other to raise and support their child, gradually allowing him to grow up.
Next to their house, there was a skilled weaver who made a living through his craft.
The elder's wife saw this and had this thought:
'Entering the ocean to trade is not as good as the craft of weaving.
Many who enter the ocean die and do not return.
As for weaving, one can always stay at home and seek one's own livelihood.'
She had another thought:
'Now I want to teach my son the weaving craft.'
Having thought this, he took his son to the weaver's house and said to the weaver:
'Elder brother!
Teach this nephew the weaving craft.'
The weaver replied:
'Good!'
He kept the son to teach him weaving.
The son was intelligent and soon learned. Every time he wove together with the weaver, they both wove. The profits he earned were taken home, but the earnings were always insufficient.
The weaver's earnings were extravagant and abundant. The nephew asked his uncle:
'Now I and my uncle work the same job, why is it that my uncle's household is always well-off, while my family is always struggling to make ends meet?'
The uncle replied to his nephew:
'I do two jobs, while you only do one.'
The nephew asked his uncle:

He then replied:

The nephew said:ğŸ”½'If I do the same, will I also get rich?'

The uncle thought:
'I will test him first.'
Having thought this, they went to the market together. The uncle bought a rabbit and told him to cook it:
'I will take a bath for a while and come back to eat.'
While the uncle was taking a bath, the nephew ate one of the legs. When the uncle came back from the bath, he asked his nephew:
'Is it cooked?'
The nephew replied:

The uncle said:

The nephew carried the rabbit over to his uncle. When the uncle saw that the rabbit was missing a leg, he asked his nephew:

' He then took the rabbit and went together into a wine shop. The uncle sat down and called his nephew to sit together. After drinking, he ordered his nephew to calculate the price of the wine.

He then went with his nephew in the middle of the night to break through other people's walls intending to steal their valuables.
After they had broken through the hole, the uncle then wanted to put his head through the hole first, but the nephew said:
